CONGRATULATIONS
are certainly due the Barnstormers for
CONGRATULATIONS
their efforts this year. In spite of the fact that the services of
their former coach were not available, that the time to prepare the annual production was greatly reduced, and an innovation in the form
of having girls take the female roles was introduced; this year's play
was a marked success. Two graduate members of the club, Howard
Caplan and William Banks, coached the play. When it was announced that these men were to direct the play this year some doubt
was manifested as to whether they were capable of producing a play
comparable to former productions of the Barnstormers. The ability of
these men as actors was recognized, but their capabilities in the coaching line were unknown. That they are equally capable both as actors
and coaches is now apparent.
The production and property staff both performed capably. The
difficult sound effects were excellent, and not a single slip was
apparent on either evening. The cast was well chosen, and performed
remarkably well on the whole.
It seems quite regrettable the Barnstormers believe it impossible to
give any further performances. We are sure that this year's production if given out of town, would be a credit to both the club and the
University.

PURE FOOTBALL

FROM a recent issue of the Brown and

White, student newspaper
of Lehigh University, we learn that the lone athletic scholarship
formerly offered at that institution has been withdrawn, and that the
faculty has passed a resolution by unanimous vote requesting the Board
of Control of Athletics to present for future faculty approval only
those schedules which were confined to schools whose athletics are
under scholastic and amateur standards. This is a worthy endeavor.
However, we doubt that Lehigh could find enough suitable opponents
whose athletic records are absolutely pure. If the fact that no athletic
scholarships were awarded, proved that the institution were athletically
pure then little trouble would be met in arranging a schedule. This
is not the principal factor in the professionalism of college athletics.
The idea has been advanced that with the expansion of professional
football, professionalism in colleges will die out. If the administrations and athletic boards of educational institutions had complete control of the situation, pure athletics could be obtained. However, it is
the alumni of the colleges and universities who are largely responsible
for the present conditions. They must have their good football teams
and as long as they continue to financially support students, professionalism will remain. It sounds very fine to say that no athletic
scholarships are awarded, but as long as certain alumni regard the
standing of the football team as more important than the educational
standards of the institution, college athletics will not be pure and athletic scholarships will be of no importance.

Sketches Moody's Life

Dr. French sketched rather hastily the life of Moody. From the
beginning, existence was a real
struggle for him, his mother and
father both having died when he
had reached the age of fifteen.
Moody's early life was spent in
both teaching a country school and
private pupils. The latter occupation presented him with an opportunity to travel abroad in Greece
and Italy, an experience most valuable to him when he turned to
poetry.
"Harvard College," said Dr.
French, "where he took his master's degree was the next scene of
his life. Again Moody returned to
teaching, which he then considered most unpleasant, since there
burned in him a desire to give expression to the emotions welling
within him. Soon his plays met
with bountiful success and he severed his teaching connection.
Moody Affected by Conditions
"It is claimed that much of his

poetry savors of the old English
style. While this is quite true in
itself, there is unquestioned originality of thought and imagination
woven into his themes.
"Moody, like other twentieth
century writers was affected tremendously by the development of
social problems and conditions, and
this note appears in much of his
composition. In his 'The Great Divide,' Moody depicts with penetrating keenness the vast difference
between the rugged and open western mind and the fine, thin New
England mind, both of which he
understood and evaluated unerringly because of his intimate association with both sections."
Play Has Specific Origin

As is true of most of his works,
the speaker affirmed, the theme for
the "Faith Healer", has a specific
origin. It is contended that he received the inspiration for this play
from one Schlatter, who believing
he was commanding the voice of
God, went about the country working miracles among the sick. Schlatter, in his travels, meets a woman.
Rhoda, with whom he falls in love.
Feeling this inconsistent with his
commission, he becomes discouraged and abandons his practice. In
his saner reflections, however, he
sees the absurdity of this idea, and
begins anew his appointed work.
The play, Dr. French asserted,
follows pretty closely on these
lines.

According to Michigan State
News, the freshmen up there must
have taken it into their heads to kid
the profs, as no one—not even
freshmen—could naturally be so
dumb. Well, we don't know about_
that, but here goes for some
samples of their stupidity. Behold
some of the answers:
A lighthouse is used for looking
out over the water from a submerged submarine.
Embalming is the art or science
of preparing, stuffing and mounting
skins of animals.
Flowers is (how's that for grammar, by the way?) the expression
of sympathy or grief.
(And, say, doesn't that furnish
an example of the effect of modern
high-pressure advertisement.)
"Alas" is said to be the verbal
expression of the above mentioned
sympathy or grief. Anyway, this
answers and also refutes the question of what modern youth is coming to. It's a sure thing that any
one who can be content with a mere
"alas" when there are so many
available cuss words in our language
can hardly be so very bad after all.
The part of the skull enclosing
the brain is called the abdomen.
The part of the skull enclosing
the brain is called the skeleton, according to another and equally high
or rather equally low authority.
A convict is one who works in
stone. (Well, anyway, that one
couldn't possibly have been seriously intended.
A professional tramp is a pest.
(See above.)
A long deep cut is called a woon.
And so on and on ad infinitum.
For the dumbness of freshmen, anthropologically speaking, certainly is
ad infinitum.
Who'd a' thought it! The puritanical New Englanders of the University of Vermont have broken out
into a rash of modernism and have
put out a tabloid newspaper—a
scandal sheet. Indeed, if the effect
of Bernarr Macfadden's best efforts
have so impressed the backwashes
of Vermont, what can be expected
from our younger generation in
Hopkins? To get back to Vermont,
the paper headlines the discovery of
a love nest of a professor on the

PURE FOOTBALL

FROM a recent issue of the Brown and

White, student newspaper
of Lehigh University, we learn that the lone athletic scholarship
formerly offered at that institution has been withdrawn, and that the
faculty has passed a resolution by unanimous vote requesting the Board
of Control of Athletics to present for future faculty approval only
those schedules which were confined to schools whose athletics are
under scholastic and amateur standards. This is a worthy endeavor.
However, we doubt that Lehigh could find enough suitable opponents
whose athletic records are absolutely pure. If the fact that no athletic
scholarships were awarded, proved that the institution were athletically
pure then little trouble would be met in arranging a schedule. This
is not the principal factor in the professionalism of college athletics.
The idea has been advanced that with the expansion of professional
football, professionalism in colleges will die out. If the administrations and athletic boards of educational institutions had complete control of the situation, pure athletics could be obtained. However, it is
the alumni of the colleges and universities who are largely responsible
for the present conditions. They must have their good football teams
and as long as they continue to financially support students, professionalism will remain. It sounds very fine to say that no athletic
scholarships are awarded, but as long as certain alumni regard the
standing of the football team as more important than the educational
standards of the institution, college athletics will not be pure and athletic scholarships will be of no importance.

Sketches Moody's Life

Dr. French sketched rather hastily the life of Moody. From the
beginning, existence was a real
struggle for him, his mother and
father both having died when he
had reached the age of fifteen.
Moody's early life was spent in
both teaching a country school and
private pupils. The latter occupation presented him with an opportunity to travel abroad in Greece
and Italy, an experience most valuable to him when he turned to
poetry.
"Harvard College," said Dr.
French, "where he took his master's degree was the next scene of
his life. Again Moody returned to
teaching, which he then considered most unpleasant, since there
burned in him a desire to give expression to the emotions welling
within him. Soon his plays met
with bountiful success and he severed his teaching connection.
Moody Affected by Conditions
"It is claimed that much of his

poetry savors of the old English
style. While this is quite true in
itself, there is unquestioned originality of thought and imagination
woven into his themes.
"Moody, like other twentieth
century writers was affected tremendously by the development of
social problems and conditions, and
this note appears in much of his
composition. In his 'The Great Divide,' Moody depicts with penetrating keenness the vast difference
between the rugged and open western mind and the fine, thin New
England mind, both of which he
understood and evaluated unerringly because of his intimate association with both sections."
Play Has Specific Origin

As is true of most of his works,
the speaker affirmed, the theme for
the "Faith Healer", has a specific
origin. It is contended that he received the inspiration for this play
from one Schlatter, who believing
he was commanding the voice of
God, went about the country working miracles among the sick. Schlatter, in his travels, meets a woman.
Rhoda, with whom he falls in love.
Feeling this inconsistent with his
commission, he becomes discouraged and abandons his practice. In
his saner reflections, however, he
sees the absurdity of this idea, and
begins anew his appointed work.
The play, Dr. French asserted,
follows pretty closely on these
lines.
